data.title: Arvind Desai Ki Ajeeb Dastaan (1978)
data.meta_description: Arvind, a rich businessman's son, dates the office secretary but is engaged to marry someone else. With a complicated family background, he struggles to find meaning in his life.
data.text:
FIRST WORLD PROBLEMS

"Son of a rich family feels trapped in his bubble of privilege, can't connect with anything deeply enough to commit himself to any concrete actions." That's not exactly a new story -- I don't think it's a coincidence that references to Hamlet were dropped into the dialogue -- and it's not an easy story to dramatize. The solution to that problem is not to dramatize anything; Arvind wanders around Mumbai, day and night, visiting with friends and... doing nothing... like he was Jean-Pierre Leaud or somebody; tellingly, he's able to resolve one conflict toward the beginning, but as his anomie deepens, we're shown the situations in which somebody gets in his face about something, but never told…

Too much to have, too little to do

Arvind Desai ki Ajeeb Daastaan is a whole film about emptiness. There is no causality to any event, no character. If there indeed is an arc of any sorts about the film it is a larger arc about a hungry capitalist pursuit of a nation that's pushing the labor to the peripheries. It's a tough film to act in not out of having any overwhelming qualities, quite the opposite tbh.

It's interesting to ponder why the story is 'ajeeb' I guess because people like Arvind Desai exist so far out from any concern of the society. To be a rich, priveliged man with nothing to strive for in a world that has…
